H0.text: Very low density is a likely property of aerogels, which are compounds formed by drying certain gels and whose particles are much farther apart than those of most solids, bonded together by strong covalently bonded bridges.

H1.text: High electrical conductivity is a likely property of aerogels, which are formed by drying certain gels into a solid material where particles are much farther apart than in most solids and are held together by covalently bonded bridges.

H2.text: Very low melting point is a likely property of aerogels, which are compounds formed by drying certain gels; although the aerogel hardens into a solid, its particles are much farther apart than those of most solids and are held together by strong covalently bonded atom bridges.

H3.text: Very flexible is a likely property of aerogels, compounds formed by the drying of certain gels that harden into a solid material yet have particles much farther apart than most solids and are held together by strong covalently bonded bridges.

A4.text: Aerogels have a porous solid network that contains air pockets, with the air pockets taking up the majority of space within the material.

A5.text: Pressing extremely firmly will cause a breakdown in the sparse structure causing it to shatter like glass (a property known as friability)
